chunks.en:
It is well known that Apple's M1 and M2 balance high performance and low energy consumption.
Moreover, there are currently some disassembled Macbook Air/Pro motherboards on the internet.
And the M1 and M2 CPUs support Linux.
So, does the 8-core M2 crush all embedded servers?

bcm2712 bcm2711
rk3566 rk3588
n100 n5105
It seems that none of them can compete with a headless M2 running Linux.

x86's overall cost-effectiveness, stability, configuration flexibility, and software ecosystem completely surpasses all ARM. Anyone slightly smarter wouldn't focus on saving a little electricity and waste time tinkering with these.
No expandability, can't handle it, and the performance is overkill, and the price is too high.

chunks.en: In fact, the ecosystem of ARM-based Macs running Linux services is worse than Raspberry Pi. At least Raspberry Pi has a lot of software specifically adapted for Raspberry Pi.
Many of Mac's advantages are also achieved by software under macOS that is specifically optimized for hardware.

Some dedicated hardware acceleration units can only be called under macOS, and because the hardware is very unified, Apple provides well-packaged upper-layer interfaces, and macOS programs can be easily integrated.
